more_info.origin: br/>Natural amino acid (building block of protein). Commercially prepared from molasses by bacterial fermentation. Also prepared from vegetable protein, such as gluten, or soy protein. Glutamic acid and glutamates are present in all proteins. Free glutamates are present in high concentrations in ripened cheese, breast milk, tomatoes and sardines.
more_info.daily_intake: br/>None determined. Glutamates may not be used in products intended for children under 12 weeks.
more_info.side_effects: br/>Although many side effects have been reported for glutamates, these have not been scientifically proven. See also   and .
more_info.dietary_restrictions: br/>None. Glutamic acid and glutamates can be used by all religious groups, vegetarians and vegans. The products do not contain gluten.

more_info.side_effects: br/>Although many side effects have been reported for glutamates, these have not been scientifically proven. See also   and .
more_info.dietary_restrictions: br/>None. Glutamic acid and glutamates can be used by all religious groups, vegetarians and vegans. The products do not contain gluten.

more_info.origin:
/strong>
Magnesium salt from glutamic acid (), a natural amino acid (building block of protein). Commercially prepared from molasses by bacterial fermentation. Also prepared from vegetable protein, such as gluten, or soy protein. Glutamic acid and glutamates are present in all proteins. Free glutamates are present in high concentrations in ripened cheese, breast milk, tomatoes and sardines.
more_info.products: br/>Hardly used, only in low sodium meat products.
more_info.daily_intake: br/>None determined. Glutamates may not be used in products intended for children under 12 weeks.
more_info.side_effects: br/>Although many side effects have been reported for glutamates, these have not been scientifically proven. See also   and .
more_info.dietary_restrictions: br/>None. Glutamic acid and glutamates can be used by all religious groups, vegetarians and vegans. The products do not contain gluten.

more_info.origin:
/strong>
Guanylic acid is a natural acid, which is part of RNA, one of the genetic carrier molecules in the cell. It is thus part of all cells in all living organisms. Commercially prepared from yeast extract or sardines.
more_info.daily_intake: br/>None determined. Guanylates may not be used in products intended for children under 12 weeks.
more_info.side_effects: br/>Asthmatic people should avoid guanylic acid and guanylates. As guanylates are metabolised to purines, they should be avoided by people suffering from gout. However, the concentrations used are generally so low that no effects are to be expected.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: br/>Guanlyic acic and guanylates are generally produced from yeasts, but partly also from fish. They may thus not suitable for vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin:
/strong>

more_info.products: br/>Used in many products, mainly in low-salt/sodium products.
more_info.daily_intake: br/>None determined. Guanylates may not be used in products intended for children under 12 weeks.
more_info.side_effects: br/>Asthmatic people should avoid guanylic acid and guanylates. As guanylates are metabolised to purines, they should be avoided by people suffering from gout. However, the concentrations used are generally so low that no effects are to be expected.

more_info.origin:
/strong>
A natural acid, that is mainly present in animals. Commercially prepared from meat or fish (sardines). May also be produced by bacterial fermentation of sugars.
more_info.daily_intake: br/>None determined. Inosinates may not be used in products intended for children under 12 weeks.
more_info.side_effects: br/>Asthmatic people should avoid inosinates. As inosinates are metabolised to purines, they should be avoided by people suffering from gout. However, the concentrations used are generally so low that no effects are to be expected.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: br/>Inosinates are generally produced from meat, but partly also from fish. They are thus not suitable for vegans and vegetarians, and in most cases not suitable for Jews, Muslims and Hindus, depending on the origin of the product. Only the producer can provide information on the origin.

more_info.origin:
/strong>

more_info.origin:
/strong>
A natural compound commercially extracted from the bark of lark trees or roasted malt. Also by heating of lactose and maltose.
more_info.products: br/>Used in many products, mainly confectionary and bakery products.
more_info.dietary_restrictions:
/strong>
Maltol is generally produced from bark or malt. Sometimes lactose (from cow's milk) is used. It should thus be avoided by vegans. It does not contain lactose and can be used by lactose-intolerant people.

more_info.origin:
/strong>
Produced from maltol (636), a natural compound commercially extracted from the bark of lark trees or roasted malt. Also by heating of lactose and maltose.
more_info.products: br/>Used in many products, mainly confectionary and bakery products.
more_info.dietary_restrictions:
/strong>
Maltol is generally produced from bark or malt. Sometimes lactose (from cow's milk) is used. It should thus be avoided by vegans. It does not contain lactose and can be used by lactose-intolerant people.

more_info.origin:
/strong>
Glycine is a natural amino acid, a building block of protein. Mainly produced from gelatin, partly synthetic.
more_info.dietary_restrictions:
/strong>
Glycine is produced mainly from gelatin, which is derived from animal bones. It is therefore not suitable for vegans, vegetarians and, as long as the origin is not known, not for Jews, Muslims and Hindus. Only the producer can provide the origin of the product.
